article.title: Revealing the structure of the outer disks of Be stars

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 1 (β CMi)**\n\n**A.** What type of star is β CMi?
**B.** What is the approximate radius of the disk (Rout) in stellar radii (Re)?
**C.** What wavelength region is most sensitive to the disk size?
**D.** What is the main discrepancy between the best-fit model and the observations?
choices: The model overestimates the UV flux.
The model underestimates the visual flux.
The model overestimates the infrared flux.
The model underestimates the flux at 6 cm.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 2 (η Tau)**\n\n**A.** What does the flat slope of the observed SED in the radio suggest about the disk?
choices: The disk density fall-off regime changes in the outer parts.
The disk is in a dissipating phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: **B.** What is the approximate radius of the disk (Rout) in stellar radii (Re)?
**C.** Which wavelength region was used to constrain the central star parameters (Rp and L)?
**D.** What does the presence of a truncated disk in η Tau suggest, considering no companion was found in adaptive optics observations?
choices: The inclination of the disk is wrong.
The disk is in a transonic regime.
A binary companion might be present but too faint to be detected.
The disk is not a VDD.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 3 (EW Lac)**\n\n**A.** What type of star is EW Lac?
**B.** What is the approximate disk size (Rout) in stellar radii (Re)?
**C.** Which wavelength region was used to determine the central star parameters (Rp and L)?
**D.** What could be a possible cause for the shallower density profile of EW Lac compared to other Be stars with similar disk densities?
choices: The disk is in a dissipating phase.
The disk is in a transonic regime.
The accumulation effect due to a close orbiting companion.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 5 (ψ Per)**\n\n**A.** What is the best-fit disk size (Rout) in stellar radii (Re)?
**B.** What was the FWHM of the Gaussian fit to the azimuthally averaged visibility data of Dougherty & Taylor (1992)?
**C.** What does the comparison of the model visibility curves with the observed data by Dougherty & Taylor (1992) suggest?
choices: The best-fit model perfectly reproduces the observations.
There are discrepancies between the model and the observations that need further investigation.
The disk size of ψ Per is much larger than previously thought.
The disk density fall-off regime is well represented by a single power law.

multiple_choice_question.text: **D.** What is the reason for scaling the visibility curves in Figure 5 so that the visibility at zero baseline is equal to unity?
choices: To simplify the comparison with the observed data.
To account for the different absolute flux densities of the models.
To emphasize the differences between the models with different disk sizes.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 6 (γ Cas)**\n\n**A.** How does the disk size determined for γ Cas compare to the critical radius (Rc)?
choices: The disk size is much larger than Rc.
The disk size is equal to Rc.
The disk size is much smaller than Rc.
The comparison is not possible due to the lack of data.

multiple_choice_question.text: **B.** What is the approximate disk size (Rout) in stellar radii (Re)?
**C.** What does the SED turndown observed in γ Cas suggest about the disk?
choices: The disk is in a transonic regime.
The disk is truncated, likely by a binary companion.
The disk is in a dissipating phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: **D.** What could be a possible explanation for the overestimation of the visual and near-IR fluxes by the model?
choices: The simplified disk model does not account for complex density structures in the inner disk.
The disk is not in a steady state.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 7 (β Mon A)**\n\n**A.** What type of star is β Mon A?
**B.** What is the best-fit disk size (Rout) in stellar radii (Re)?
**C.** What is the main challenge in determining the disk size for β Mon A?
choices: The disk is in a transonic regime.
The available radio data set is limited.
The disk is in a dissipating phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: **D.** What could be a possible explanation for the flat slope of the observed radio SED?
choices: The presence of disk material overflowing beyond the truncation radius.
The disk is in a transonic regime.
The disk is in a dissipating phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: **Figure 8 (po and n distributions)**\n\n**A.** What does the position of the stars studied in this work on Figure 8 suggest about their disks?
choices: The disks are mostly in a dissipating phase.
The disks are mostly in a steady state.
The disks are mostly in the process of formation.

multiple_choice_question.text: **B.** What is the main difference between the results of this study and the study by Vieira et al. (2017)?
choices: This study uses a different model to determine the po and n parameters.
This study finds a higher prevalence of steeper density profiles (n~3).
This study uses a different sample of Be stars.
This study includes radio observations in the SED modeling.

multiple_choice_question.text: **C.** What could be a possible explanation for the presence of shallow density profiles (n < 3) in Be stars with stable disks?
choices: The disks are in a dissipating phase.
The disks are in a transonic regime.
The accumulation effect due to unseen binary companions.

multiple_choice_question.text: **D.** What is the purpose of Figure 8?
choices: To show the distribution of effective temperatures of Be stars.
To compare the results of this study with previous studies.
To show the correlation between the po and n parameters.
